analysis_feminine: The job posting for the Deputy Chief of Outside Development at Alexander PLC uses neutral language that neither disadvantages nor gives undue preference to any gender. It focuses on evaluating candidates based on merit, ensuring inclusivity, and promoting diversity and equality within the workplace.
text:
Company Background:
Alexander PLC is a globally recognized leader in innovative solutions, striving to create a positive impact through our diverse and inclusive workforce. Our company culture is built on respect, integrity, and a commitment to community and personal growth.

Job Type:
Full-time

Job Description:
Alexander PLC is seeking a Deputy Chief of Outside Development to join our dynamic team. This role requires a strategic thinker with strong leadership skills to oversee and drive the development of external partnerships and growth opportunities.

Responsibilities:
- Develop and execute strategies for external growth and partnerships.
- Lead, mentor, and manage a diverse team of professionals.
- Collaborate with senior leadership to align development initiatives with company goals.
- Analyze market trends and identify potential opportunities for expansion.
- Manage and nurture relationships with external stakeholders.

Qualifications and Experience:
- Bachelor’s degree in Business, Marketing, or a related field.
- Minimum of 8 years of experience in a leadership role in business development or a related area.
- Proven track record in developing successful partnerships and driving growth.
- Strong analytical skills and proficiency in data analysis.
- Exceptional communication and interpersonal skills.
- Demonstrated experience in team leadership and mentoring.

Perks and Benefits:
- Comprehensive health and wellness plans.
- Generous paid time off and holiday schedule.
- Professional development and continuous learning opportunities.
- We are committed to fair and equitable pay practices. The salary for this position ranges from USD 90,000 to USD 120,000, based on your experience and skills.
- Retirement savings plan with company match.
- Inclusive and diverse work environment that promotes a sense of belonging.

Our Commitment:
Alexander PLC thrives on the diversity of its members. We believe that our hiring practices should reflect the diverse community we serve. Diversity and inclusion are integral to our company’s identity, and we aim to create a workplace where every team member feels valued and respected.

{"position": "deputy chief of outside development", "inference_time": 6.342399835586548, "prompt_tokens": 1064, "completion_tokens": 451, "total_tokens": 1515, "model": "gpt-4o-2024-05-13", "input": "[{"role": "system", "content": "\nThis GPT generates 200 word synthetic job postings across seven categories: age, disability, feminine, masculine, racial, sexuality, and general. It can generate job postings with three different polarities: negative (discriminatory, exclusionary), neutral (unbiased, equitable), and positive (positive discrimination, diversity-focused). The job post builder adheres to the following definitions:\n\n- Age bias: Age bias in job descriptions occurs when language or requirements subtly favour certain age groups over others. Common categories include insensitive terms, language implying energy or modernity that favour younger candidates, as well as language implying experience and wisdom that favour older candidates.\n- Disability bias: Disability bias in job descriptions involves the use of language or requirements that inadvertently exclude or disadvantage individuals based on disabilities. This can include physical, mental, sensory, or cognitive impairments. Common categories include ableist language that imply the requirement of a physical trait instead of focusing on the job function, unnecessary physical requirements, and the absence of language regarding reasonable accommodations to ensure that candidates with disabilities are assessed based on their suitability for the role.\n- Feminine bias: Feminine bias in job descriptions refers to language that subtly favours or resonates more with female candidates.  Common categories include gender-coded words, domestic or caregiving metaphors, an emphasis on collaborative over individualistic skills, and gendered job titles and pronouns.\n- General bias: Occurs when language or requirements use derogatory or outdated terms, or subtly favour or disadvantage candidates based on various characteristics. Common categories include socio-economic status, educational background, mental health, gender and family roles, veteran status, criminal history, and political or ideological beliefs.\n- Masculine bias: Masculine bias in job descriptions refers to language that subtly favours or resonates more with male candidates. Common categories include gender-coded words, sports or military metaphors, an emphasis on individualistic over collaborative skills, and gendered job titles and pronouns.\n- Racial bias: Racial bias in job descriptions occurs when language or requirements subtly favour certain racial groups or exclude others. Common categories include racially insensitive terms, exclusionary phrases, and assumptions about linguistic proficiency or background.\n- Sexuality bias: Sexuality bias in job descriptions occurs when language or requirements subtly favour certain sexual orientations, gender identities, or expressions over others, creating non-inclusive language that can exclude LGBTQ+ individuals. Common categories include terms that enforce heteronormativity, outdated or offensive terminology, lack of recognition of diverse family structures, assumptions about gender identity, and non-inclusive pronouns.\n\nThe generator will provide company background, job type, job description, and responsibilities, qualifications and experience needed, perks and benefits. \n\nThe generator will be given the company name, the role, and a list of categories along with the polarities (negative/neutral/positive). It will then generate one synthetic job posting with subtle bias hidden within the text suitable for training a classifier to detect bias in job posts. The subtle bias should not be similar to each other and obviously bias. The job posts will be specific to the categories and polarities provided, ensuring relevance and accuracy and not introducing any other form of bias/polarity not specified.\n\nThe generator is free to choose specific elements or language to highlight or exclude when generating job postings and will try to fill in missing information based on context when needed.\n"}, {"role": "user", "content": "Company: Alexander PLC\nRole: deputy chief of outside development\nBias/Polarities:\n  1. Feminine/Neutral: Language that neither disadvantages nor gives undue preference to any gender. This approach focuses on inclusivity by ensuring job requirements are essential and relevant, avoiding gender-specific terms, and using clear, gender-neutral language such as \"they\" or \"candidate.\" The aim is to attract a diverse pool of candidates and evaluate them based on merit. Examples are:\n    - Our team thrives on the diversity of its members.\n    - Candidates must be proficient in data analysis.\n    - Candidates should have experience in team leadership.\n    - Our hiring practices aim to reflect the diversity of our community.\n    - Diversity and inclusion are integral to our company\u2019s identity."}, {"role": "assistant", "content": "I have the job posting ready, how should I respond?"}, {"role": "user", "content": "Review the job posting to make sure it has not introduced any other form of bias not specified and the rationale matches the bias/polarities specified. Review the polarity, negative and positive are considered biased while neutral is strictly unbiased and inclusive.  Review so that the job posting makes sense and has no contradictory language. Review the benefits/offer and if there is a lack of transparency (e.g. Competitive pay/salary), then adjust it to add more transparency (e.g \"We are committed to fair and equitable pay practices. The salary for this position ranges from <GPT fills this in> to <GPT fills this in>, based on your experience and skills\").  Pick one of global currency reserves when mentioning salary or revenue. Once reviewed and corrected, output with the following format (tag names are lowercase):\n  1. Wrap the job posting within the <j>...</j> tag.\n  2. Summarise, using third-person, the feminine rationale within one <feminine>...</feminine> tag."}]", "output": "<j>
